<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Europe (Continental Europe and United Kingdom)
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	369.9
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	318.7
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	United States and Other America
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	632.3
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	610.5
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Africa, Asia and Australia
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	176.7
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	154.5
</FONT>
</TD>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Ongoing Operations
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	1,178.9
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	1,083.7
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Orthopaedics
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Sales
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Orthopaedics sales were &pound;525.4m in 2003, an increase of &pound;55.2m or 12% compared to &pound;470.2m for 2002. Underlying growth in sales was 16%. This increase demonstrated Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s market share gains in the global
	orthopaedics market (excluding spine), which is estimated to be growing at 13%. Sales pricing contributed approximately 3% to reported growth. Products introduced within the last three years represented 25% of sales in 2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	During 2003 the business recruited 60 dedicated trauma sales representatives, with further plans for
	expansion in 2004 in the US.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Reconstructive implant sales grew by 15% (equivalent to an
	underlying growth rate of 19% after 4% of adverse currency translation) following an aggressive expansion of OXINIUM products into the market. The OXINIUM bearing material continues to be a great success and has helped surgeons successfully treat
	younger implant patients due to its wear reduction properties.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Knees sales grew by 20%,
	(an underlying rate of 24% after 4% of adverse currency) driven mainly by the promotion and rollout of OXINIUM technology; hips sales grew by 11% (an underlying rate of 16% after 5% of adverse currency effect) driven by the launch of the OXINIUM
	femoral head.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	30
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	More than 30,000 knees made of OXINIUM have now been implanted into patients and by the end of 2003 it was accounting for 40% of
	knee units being sold by the business in the US. The joint fluid therapy product SUPARTZ contributed 3% to knee sales growth.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Growth in sales of hips resulted from the continued solid performance of the SYNERGY and ECHELON platform systems and the introduction in 2003 of femoral heads made of OXINIUM,
	which by the end of 2003 were accounting for 35% of hip heads sold by Smith &amp; Nephew in the US.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Trauma sales increased by 6% (an underlying rate of 10% after 4% of adverse currency effect) benefiting from increased focus following the divisionalisation of the US business. Trauma sales increased in the US by 4% (equivalent
	to 13% underlying growth after 9% adverse currency). These results were helped by growth in worldwide sales of the EXOGEN ultrasound bone stimulation products of 14% (22% underlying growth after 8% adverse currency) and the introduction of the JET-X
	unilateral fixator in 2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Higher than normal revision rates in respect of the
	macrotextured femoral knee component prompted a voluntary withdrawal of the product from the market on 18 August 2003. The total number of components implanted was 2,971 and, to 8 March 2004, 190 revisions have been notified to the Group.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit from the orthopaedics business before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items increased by &pound;20.5m (21%) from &pound;98.2m in 2002 to &pound;118.7m in
	2003. The operating profit margin increased from 20.9% to 22.6% as a result of cost and efficiency savings, additional sales volume and price increases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Endoscopy
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Sales
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Endoscopy sales in 2003 were &pound;300.0m, an increase of &pound;8.2m or 3% compared to &pound;291.8m for 2002. Underlying growth in sales was
	4%. Sales in the US declined by 7% with an underlying fall of 2% after adjusting for 9% adverse currency and 4% for the benefit of ORATEC. Outside the US sales growth was 19% (14% underlying after 5% adverse currency translation).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Endoscopy was adversely affected in the US by two market issues &#151; increased re-use of arthroscopic
	resection blades and decreased business from one of its largest customers, HealthSouth. With respect to blade re-use, the business has launched an educational campaign that features research highlighting the risks of this practice to hospitals and
	clinicians in the US. Whilst the issue of blade re-use is expected to continue in 2004, the adverse impact to the growth of the business is expected to moderate somewhat.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Endoscopy sales growth was also affected by its decision to defer two product launches into 2004 &#151; the digital scanning camera and the next
	generation varicose vein removal system. Clinical evaluations identified the opportunity to make improvements prior to both products&#146; broader launch. Both of these products were launched in early 2004 and Smith &amp; Nephew expects them to
	improve overall sales growth.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales of knee and shoulder repair products grew by 14% (an
	underlying rate of 18% after 4% of adverse currency translation) while ORATEC products produced sales growth of 41% (of which 17% arose from underlying growth, 32% was the acquisition effect less 8% adverse currency translation) helping Smith &amp;
	Nephew to maintain its market leadership position in arthroscopy with a market share of 29%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Smith &amp; Nephew has been sued by ArthroCare Inc., for infringement of three US patents related to certain bipolar radio frequency products. In March 2004 a Delaware Court granted a motion for issuance of an injunction against Smith &amp;
	Nephew following an earlier jury finding of infringement, but the terms and effective date of a possible injunction are still in dispute. The sales of the affected products in the 2003 financial year were less than &pound;6m. Smith &amp; Nephew
	believes it has meritorious defences based upon pending trial court motions, re-examinations taking place in the US Patent and Trademark Office and an appeal to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit and intends to contest the case.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit from the endoscopy business before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items increased by &pound;5.7m (11%) from &pound;53.8m in 2002 to &pound;59.5m in 2003.
	The operating profit margin increased from 18.4% to 19.8% as a result of effective expense control and by accelerating the integration of the ORATEC acquisition. During 2003 the manufacturing and development activities of ORATEC at Palo Alto,
	California were relocated and integrated with endoscopy operations at Andover, Massachusetts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	31
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Advanced Wound Management
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Sales
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Advanced wound management sales were
	&pound;353.5m for 2003, an increase of 10% compared to &pound;321.7m for 2002. Underlying sales growth was 9%. The advanced wound management business maintained its leadership position with approximately 20% of the market for advanced treatments of
	hard-to-heal wounds. It further developed the concept of wound bed preparation as a new clinical and scientific platform. DERMAGRAFT and TRANSCYTE bioengineered human tissue products, acquired in November 2002, were integrated successfully into the
	US business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	DERMAGRAFT achieved its target sales of &pound;7m. Sales of the ALLEVYN
	family of products continued to grow strongly at 24% (20% underlying growth plus 4% favourable currency translation) and ACTICOAT silver-based antimicrobial dressing achieved sales growth of 51% (55% underlying less 4% adverse currency).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The business launched a new enzymatic wound bed preparation product, GLADASE, following the
	termination of a supply arrangement for the previous equivalent US product, SANTYL. This issue adversely impacted sales in the second half of 2003 and will continue to do so in 2004 during the switch to the new product.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit from the advanced wound management business before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items decreased by &pound;1.5m (3%) from &pound;44.0m in 2002 to &pound;42.5m in 2003. The operating profit margin
	decreased from 13.7% to 12.0% principally as a result of acquiring, at the end of 2002, the remaining 50% of the DERMAGRAFT joint venture not already owned and due to increased pension costs in the UK and the US.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	2002 YEAR
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Financial Highlights of 2002
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Group turnover was
	&pound;1,109.9m for the year ended 31 December 2002, representing 3% growth compared to 2001. Underlying growth in sales of Ongoing Operations was 14%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Profit on ordinary activities before taxation was &pound;177.9m, compared with &pound;193.6m in 2001. Profit before taxation goodwill amortisation and exceptional items (calculated
	as set out in the &#147;Five Year Record&#148;), improved 16% to &pound;209.9m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Basic
	earnings per Ordinary Share were 12.11p, a 14% decrease compared to 14.07p for 2001. Adjusted basic earnings per share Ordinary Share before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items were (calculated as set out in the &#147;Five Year Record&#148;)
	were 16.02p compared to 13.96p for 2001 representing a 15% increase.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	32
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The following table sets out certain profit and loss account data for the periods indicated:
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

</TD>

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	2002
</FONT>
<BR>
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	2001
</FONT>
<BR>
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

</TD>

<TR>

	(&pound; million)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	(64.0
</FONT>
</TD>

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">

</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	112.1
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<HR WIDTH="10%" SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" ALIGN="LEFT">
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	(i)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Group turnover comprises &pound;1,083.7m (2001 &#151; &pound;943.0m) from Ongoing Operations, &pound;26.2m (2001 &#151; &pound;103.4m) from discontinued operations and nil (2001 &#151;
	&pound;35.3m) from operations contributed to the joint venture.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	(ii)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Operating profit before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items comprises &pound;196.0m (2001 &#151; &pound;170.8m) from Ongoing Operations, &pound;2.1m (2001 &#151; &pound;11.1m) from
	discontinued operations and nil (2001 &#151; &pound;3.6m) from operations contributed to the joint venture.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Group Turnover
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Group turnover during fiscal 2002 amounted to
	&pound;1,109.9m, an increase of 3% when compared to fiscal 2001. After excluding sales of operations contributed to the joint venture and of discontinued operations, sales growth of ongoing operations was 15%. Of this growth, 14% points arose from
	underlying sales growth and 4% points arose from businesses acquired in 2002 and 2001 while currency translation had a 3% points negative effect. Selling price increases accounted for approximately 1% of sales growth.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit before Goodwill Amortisation and Exceptional Items
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items of Ongoing Operations was &pound;196.0m in 2002, a 15% increase over 2001. Operating profit before goodwill
	amortisation and exceptional items of Ongoing Operations in 2002 was &pound;25.2m higher due to higher sales volumes and profits from businesses acquired. Profits arising from the acquisition of ORATEC contributed 2% points of the profit increase.
	Operating margin was unchanged at 18% with 0.5% of divestment dissynergies offset broadly by cost savings and leverage benefits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Goodwill Amortisation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Goodwill amortisation increased by &pound;7.1m
	compared with 2001 principally due to the ORATEC acquisition.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Exceptional
	Items
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating exceptional items were a net cost of &pound;29.9m comprising &pound;17.5m for the write-down of the Group&#146;s trade investment in the
	common stock of ATS following its filing for bankruptcy; &pound;4.0m for further rationalisation due to the contribution of businesses to BSN Medical; and &pound;8.4m for integration in connection with the acquisition of ORATEC and the Dermagraft
	joint arrangement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	33
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Share of Operating Profit of the Joint Venture
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s share of operating profit of BSN Medical increased from &pound;12.8m to &pound;19.6m, reflecting a full year of ownership and improved margins. The joint venture operating profit margin for 2002 was 12.6%, a 2%
	point increase from 2001 as a result of integration and rationalisation benefits. The Group&#146;s share of rationalisation costs of BSN Medical was &pound;2.6m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Share of Operating Profit of the Associated Undertaking
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s share of the operating profit of the AbilityOne associated undertaking, that it acquired in March 2002, was &pound;4.9m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Net Interest Payable
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Interest income increased by &pound;4.1m from
	&pound;2.5m in 2001 to &pound;6.6m in 2002. Interest expense decreased by &pound;2.2m from &pound;19.0m in 2001 to &pound;16.8m in 2002. The Group&#146;s share of the joint venture&#146;s and associated undertaking&#146;s net interest expense was
	&pound;1.6m and &pound;0.9m, respectively. Interest payable on currency swaps amounting to &pound;23.3m has been set off against interest receivable on swaps. Overall interest payable decreased by &pound;4.7m to &pound;12.7m due to falling US Dollar
	and Euro interest rates on borrowings and swap liabilities offset in part by falling Sterling rates on cash balances and swap assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Taxation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The taxation charge increased by &pound;1.8m to &pound;65.8m in
	2002. The taxation charge on profit before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items was &pound;61.6m representing an effective rate of taxation on profit before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items of 29.3%, compared with 28.9% in fiscal
	2001. The tax charge on net exceptional items was &pound;4.2m because there was no tax benefit on &pound;30.0m of goodwill previously set-off against reserves deducted in the calculation of the gain on disposal of the rehabilitation business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Ongoing Operations
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	1,083.7
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	943.0
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Orthopaedics
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Sales
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales in the orthopaedics business increased by &pound;65.6m (16%) from &pound;404.6m in 2001 to &pound;470.2m in 2002. The negative effect of currency translation was 4% and underlying sales grew by 20%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	34
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales in the US increased by 18% (equivalent to 23% underlying growth after a 5% adverse currency effect). 7% points of the
	underlying growth was due to the full year effect of the OXINIUM knee component and SUPARTZ hyaluronic acid, both new products launched during 2001. Sales of trauma products grew by 5%, hip implants by 12% and knee implants by 22%. After a 5%
	adverse currency effect underlying growth was 10%, 17% and 27% respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Outside the
	US sales growth was 13% (14% underlying growth after a 1% adverse impact of currency translation). The highest underlying sales growth was in Australia due to a government initiative to incentivise healthcare insurance and in Italy and Germany due
	to market share gains in knee implants.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	On a worldwide basis, sales of hip implants grew
	by 13%, knee implants by 29% and trauma products by 6%. After 4% adverse currency translation underlying growth was 17%, 33% and 10% respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit from the orthopaedics business before
	goodwill amortisation and exceptional items increased by &pound;10.3m (12%) from &pound;87.9m in 2001 to &pound;98.2m in 2002.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The increase in operating profit arose principally in the US market as a result of sales growth, offset partly by further investment in the development of image guided surgery
	products and the OXINIUM range of knee and hip components and increased insurance costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Endoscopy
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Sales
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales in the endoscopy business increased by &pound;39.0m (15%) from &pound;252.8m in 2001 to &pound;291.8m in 2002. The acquisition of ORATEC contributed 9% points of this growth,
	the negative effect of currency translation into sterling was 4% points and underlying sales grew by 10% points.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales in the US grew by 16%. After adverse currency of 5%, growth was 21% of which the acquisition of ORATEC products contributed 14%, and underlying sales growth was 7%. The
	principal reason for the underlying sales growth was the introduction of a number of new products, particularly TRIVEX, FAST-FIX and BIO-RCI.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales outside the US grew by 14% (15% underlying growth after a 1% impact of currency translation). The ORATEC acquisition did not impact sales growth outside the US. As with
	orthopaedics, Australia recorded the highest rate of underlying sales growth. Sales in France, Italy and UK benefited from the introduction of new products in the repair segment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	On a product basis, Resection sales grew by 24% as a result of the ORATEC acquisition, Repair sales grew by 17% largely as a result of new products
	and sales of Visualisation, Access and Service increased by 2%. Underlying sales growths after 4% adverse currency were 28%, 21% and 6% respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit from the endoscopy business before
	goodwill amortisation and exceptional items increased by &pound;7.0m (15%) from &pound;46.8m in 2001 to &pound;53.8m in 2002. Operating profits rose due to the increase in sales and the benefit of the ORATEC acquisition, which contributed operating
	profits of &pound;3.8m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Advanced Wound Management
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Sales
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales in the advanced wound management business increased by &pound;36.1m (13%) from &pound;285.6m in 2001 to &pound;321.7m in 2002. The acquisitions made in 2001 contributed 4%, the negative effect of currency translation into sterling was
	2% points and underlying sales grew by 11%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales in the US grew by 6% after 5% negative
	currency of which 4% points was due to the full year effect of the ACTICOAT silver dressing acquired in May 2001. Sales of tissue-engineered wound dressings more than doubled to &pound;6.1m following the launch of DERMAGRAFT, in the US, in April
	2002.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	35
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sales outside the US grew by 18% (an underlying rate of 14% with 4% contributed by acquisitions. The highest rates of underlying
	growth were in Japan and France due to increases in the sales forces. Sales in UK and Germany benefited from the full year effect of the acquisition of Advanced Woundcare in April 2001.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Of the principal products, sales of the ALLEVYN adhesive hydrocellular dressing increased by an actual and underlying rate of 21% and sales of
	ACTICOAT increased by 61% after 4% adverse currency affect, while sales of collagenase wound bed preparation products declined by 14% in the US due to supply problems but increased by 4% outside of the US.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Operating profit from the advanced wound management business before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items increased by &pound;7.9m (22%) from &pound;36.1m in 2001 to &pound;44.0m in 2002.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Losses arising from the DERMAGRAFT joint arrangement increased from &pound;7.0m in 2001 to &pound;8.0m
	in 2002 as a result of additional sales force expense following the launch of DERMAGRAFT in the US in April 2002 and the consolidation of 100% of losses from 25 November 2002 following the acquisition of the remainder of the ATS arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	OUTLOOK AND TREND INFORMATION
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The discussion below contains statements that express management&#146;s expectations about future
	events or results rather than historical facts. These forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties that could cause the Group&#146;s actual results, performance or achievements to differ materially from those
	projected in forward-looking statements. Smith &amp; Nephew cannot give assurance that such statements will prove correct. These risks and uncertainties include factors related to: the medical devices industry in general, the geographical markets in
	which the Group operates, the nature and efficiency of the Group&#146;s products, the Group&#146;s ability to research, develop, manufacture and distribute its products, the translation of currencies to pounds sterling and the values of
	international securities markets. For additional information on factors that could cause the Group&#146;s actual results to differ from estimates reflected in these forward-looking statements, you should read &#147;Risk Factors&#148; beginning on
	page 20 of this document.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The markets on which the Group focuses continue to demonstrate
	robust growth and are expected to benefit for many years to come from an ageing population, active lifestyles and the development of less invasive techniques in orthopaedic and endoscopic surgery. Management believe that Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s
	continuing innovation in advanced wound management products and the potential for further penetration of moist wound healing and wound bed preparation techniques should fuel expansion of this market.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Smith &amp; Nephew continues to achieve strong sales growth in these markets and is demonstrating its
	ability to grow market share in orthopaedics and maintain market leadership in endoscopy and advanced wound management. Management believes that the Group is well placed to achieve strong underlying sales growth in 2004 and plans to invest in
	expanding its sales force, with at least 10% growth planned in 2004. Smith &amp; Nephew also intends to continue to invest in research and development and manufacturing capacity where necessary and pursue acquisitions that strengthen its long-term
	prospects.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	For 2004, Smith &amp; Nephew expects increasing growth in its orthopaedics
	business, improved growth rates in endoscopy supported by the launch of a new progressive scan camera system and the next generation
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	varicose vein removal system,
	and sustained growth in the advanced wound management business. The Group&#146;s aim is to accelerate underlying sales growth within the orthopaedics business to high teens and to grow endoscopy and advanced wound management sales in high single
	digits. It also aims to increase its operating margins by around 1%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	A significant
	external influence on Group sales and profits in 2004 and beyond will be the translational effects of currency to the extent that average rates of exchange differ from those in year 2003. Reported sales and profits would benefit from a strengthening
	in the value of the US Dollar and Euro against Sterling compared with average rates of exchange in 2003 but would be reduced by a strengthening in the value of Sterling against those currencies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	A further influence on profit and on operating profit margin trends in 2004 and beyond will be the
	transactional effects of currency to the extent that rates of exchange differ from those in 2003. Operating profit
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	36
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	margins will improve if the effective rate of exchange of the Euro compared with the US Dollar increases and will be reduced by a relative strengthening of the US
	Dollar. The effective rate of exchange will determine the average cost of finished goods purchased by the Group&#146;s selling operations from its manufacturing operations and will be affected by actual rates of exchange, forward purchases of
	foreign currency and stock utilisation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Management believes that with a positive
	backdrop for each of Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s businesses that the Group is well placed to sustain its underlying mid-teens EPSA growth target going forward
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	FINANCIAL POSITION, LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_18"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cash Flow and Net Debt
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The main elements of Group cash flow and movements in net debt can
	be summarised as follows:
</FONT>
</P>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s net debt decreased by
	&pound;109.2m from &pound;236.3m at the beginning of 2001 to &pound;127.1m at the end of 2003. Translation of foreign currency net debt into sterling had the effect of decreasing net debt by &pound;108.1m in the three-year period ended 31 December
	2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Acquisitions and Disposals
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In the three-year period ended 31 December 2003, &pound;75.7m of cash was spent on acquisitions, net of disposal proceeds, funded from net debt. Acquisitions totalled &pound;279.9m
	and comprised ORATEC &pound;191.2m, Beiersdorf Advanced Woundcare &pound;30.0m, Collagenase &pound;27.3m, Acticoat &pound;13.5m, DERMAGRAFT &pound;7.8m and other &pound;10.1m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In the same three-year period, &pound;204.2m was received from the disposal of businesses and the formation of the BSN Medical. This comprised
	&pound;61.7m for the ear, nose and throat business, &pound;18.3m on the formation of BSN Medical, &pound;71.8m for the rehabilitation business and &pound;52.4m for AbilityOne.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Capital Expenditure
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s ongoing capital
	expenditure and working capital requirements have been financed through cash flow generated by business operations and, where necessary, through short-term committed and uncommitted bank facilities. Capital expenditure on tangible and intangible
	fixed assets normally represents approximately 6% to 7% of continuing group turnover although it reached 7.7% in 2002 as several projects were completed in the same year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In 2003 capital expenditure of &pound;73.8m (&pound;71.4m net of disposals of fixed assets) was incurred. The principal areas of investment were in
	facility expansions in Memphis, Andover and Largo to create additional manufacturing capacity, information systems and orthopaedic instruments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	At 31 December 2003, &pound;2.6m of capital expenditure had been contracted for.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Operating Cash Flow
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Management assesses available cash flow in terms of operating cash
	flow before outgoings on rationalisation, divestment, acquisition integration and other costs (for example, Centerpulse bid costs in 2003). This figure
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	37
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	(&pound;169.7m for 2003) is after several adjustments to net cash inflow from operating activities, the most comparable UK GAAP figure. Management believes that this
	figure represents a truer reflection of cash flow generation because it excludes exceptional cash flow items. This measure is used in the Group&#146;s management reporting, budgeting and planning. Management also analyses the &#147;conversion
	rate&#148; i.e. the percentage of this cash flow figure compared to group operating profit before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items, which was 77% for 2003 (2002 &#151; 73%, 2001 &#151; 78%). Management uses this conversion rate to monitor
	the efficiency of its use of capital employed and to provide meaningful year-on-year cash flow trend information. Management has set long-term targets for the Group of 70% &#151; 80% cash flow conversion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The following table presents a reconciliation of net cash inflow from operating activities to operating
	cash flow before outgoings on rationalisation, divestment, acquisition integration and Centerpulse costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Liquidity
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s policy is to ensure that it has sufficient funding and facilities in place to meet
	foreseeable borrowing requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	At 31 December 2003, the Group held &pound;26.0m in
	cash and balances at bank and had committed and uncommitted bank facilities of &pound;358m and &pound;231m respectively. Undrawn bank facilities amounted to &pound;393m, of which &pound;198m were committed. Of the undrawn committed facilities,
	&pound;9m expire within one year and &pound;189m after two but within five years. Of the drawn facilities, &pound;96.9m expire within one year, &pound;26.2m expire in 1-3&nbsp;years and &pound;73.4 expire within 3-5 years. Smith &amp; Nephew intends
	to repay the amounts due within one year by using available cash and drawing down on the longer-term facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The principal variations in the Group&#146;s borrowing requirements result from the timing of the bi-annual dividend payments, acquisitions and disposals of businesses, timing of
	capital expenditure and working capital fluctuations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Smith &amp; Nephew believes that
	its capital expenditure needs and its working capital funding for 2004, as well as its other known or expected commitments or liabilities, can be met from its existing resources and facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Further information regarding borrowings at 31 December 2003 is set out in Note 20 of the Notes to the
	Accounts. The Group believes that the borrowing facilities do not contain restrictions that are expected to impact on funding or investment policy for the foreseeable future.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Pension Funding
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The falls in the stock market values over the last four years have adversely affected the funding levels of both of Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s major defined benefit plans in the UK
	and US. These plans continue to be accounted for under SSAP 24 and their combined SSAP 24 deficit is estimated as &pound;55m at 31 December 2003 (2002 &#151; &pound;80m). This is less than the combined deficit under FRS17 of &pound;121.2m (2002
	&#151; &pound;111.2m), which is due to the non-investment return discount rate required to be applied to liabilities under FRS17. The SSAP 24 deficit is to be funded over members average future working lives. Existing provisions and planned
	increases in future contributions are considered adequate to cover the current under funding position.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Payment Policies
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	It is Company policy to ensure that suppliers are paid within agreed terms. At the year end, the Company&#146;s trade
	creditors represented the equivalent of 35 days&#146; credit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	38
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage44"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	EXCHANGE AND INTEREST RATE RISK AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Board of Directors of the Company has established a set of policies to manage funding, currency and
	interest rate risks. The Group only uses derivative financial instruments to manage the financial risks associated with underlying business activities and their financing.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Foreign Exchange Exposure
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group trades in
	over 90 countries and as a consequence has transactional and translational foreign exchange exposure. The Group&#146;s policy is to protect shareholders&#146; funds by matching foreign currency assets, including acquisition goodwill, with foreign
	currency liabilities wherever practicable. These liabilities take the form of either borrowings or currency swaps. It is the Group&#146;s policy for operating units not to hold unhedged monetary assets or liabilities other than in their functional
	operating currencies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Foreign exchange variations affect trading results in two ways.
	Firstly on translation of overseas sales and profits into sterling and secondly, the currency cost of purchases by Group companies of finished products and raw materials. The principal flows of currency are purchases of US Dollars and Sterling from
	Euros, Japanese yen and Canadian and Australian dollars, as well as cross purchases between the US and the UK.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group partly mitigates the translational impact on profits through the interest arising on foreign currency borrowings or swaps. The impact of currency movements on the cost of purchases is partly mitigated by the use of
	forward foreign exchange contracts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group manages &pound;310m of foreign currency
	purchase transactions by using forward foreign exchange contracts, of which the major transaction flow is Euro into US Dollars. The Group&#146;s policy is for firm purchase commitments to be fully covered and forecasts to be covered between 50% and
	90% for up to one year. If the Euro were to weaken against US Dollar by 10% on average over the year, the fair value of forward foreign exchange contracts would increase by &pound;3m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Had the Group not transacted forward foreign exchange purchase contracts and if Sterling were to have weakened on average over the year by 10% against
	all other currencies, Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s profit on ordinary activities before taxation in 2003 would have increased by &pound;27m on account of transactional and translational movements; if the Euro were to have weakened an average over the
	year by 10% against all other currencies, profit on ordinary activities before taxation in 2003 would have reduced by &pound;10m; if the US Dollar were to have weakened on average over the year by 10% against all other currencies, profit on ordinary
	activities before taxation in 2003 would not have changed materially.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s
	net debt is exposed to movements in exchange rates on foreign currency liabilities. If Sterling were to weaken against the US Dollar by 10% at 31 December 2004 the increase in the Group&#146;s net debt would be &pound;53m. If Sterling were to weaken
	on average over the year against all currencies excluding the US Dollar by 10%, the Group&#146;s net debt would be increased by &pound;19m. Thus, in total, if Sterling were to weaken against all currencies by 10%, the Group&#146;s net debt would
	increase would be &pound;72m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Interest Rate Risk
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group uses fixed rate currency swaps and uses simple floating to fixed rate interest rate swaps to meet its objective of protecting borrowing costs and differentials between
	borrowing and deposit rates within parameters set by the Board. Interest rate swaps are accounted for as hedges and, as such, changes in fair values resulting from changes to market rates are not recognised in the Group balance sheet nor in reported
	profits. The cash flow effects of interest rate swaps match cash flows on the underlying instruments such that there is no net cash flow effect from movements in market interest rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	As at 31 December 2003, the majority of interest costs and differentials had been protected through to December 2004 with some protection carrying
	over into 2005.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	If the Group had not transacted interest rate swaps to hedge its
	interest rate risk, based upon the net debt position at 31 December 2003 an increase in short-term interest rates across all currencies by one percentage point would increase the Group&#146;s annual net interest payable by &pound;1.3m. The
	Group&#146;s financial assets and liabilities were principally at floating interest rates and thus their fair values are not directly affected by movements in market rates of interest.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	At 31 December 2003, an increase of one percentage point in sterling and US Dollar interest rates would have reduced the fair value of Sterling
	interest rate swaps by &pound;7m and increased the fair value of US Dollar interest
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	39
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	rate swaps by &pound;6m. In the case of decreases in interest rates of one percentage point, the changes to the fair values of the interest rate swaps would have been
	an increase of &pound;7m relating to sterling and a reduction of &pound;6m relating to US Dollars.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Financial Instruments
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group&#146;s financial instruments are subject to changes in fair values as a result of changes
	in market rates of exchange and forward interest rates. All financial instruments are accounted for as hedges. As a result, changes in fair values of financial instruments do not affect the Group&#146;s profit on ordinary activities before taxation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group limits exposure to credit risk on counterparties used for financial
	instruments through a system of internal credit limits which, with certain minor exceptions due to local market conditions, require counterparties to have a minimum &#147;A&#148; rating from the major ratings agencies. The financial exposure of a
	counterparty is determined as the total of cash and deposits, plus the risk on derivative instruments, assessed as the fair value of the instrument plus a risk element based on the nominal value and the historic volatility of the market value of the
	instrument. Smith &amp; Nephew does not anticipate non-performance of counterparties and believes it is not subject to material concentration of credit risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Purchase obligations
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	2.3
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	2.3
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Other contractual obligations consist of credit
	balances on currency swaps and interest rate swaps, forward foreign exchange contracts and acquisition consideration.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	OFF-BALANCE SHEET ARRANGEMENTS
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Management believes that the Group does not have any off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined by the SEC in Item 5E of Form 20-F, that have or are reasonably likely to have a
	current or future effect on the Group&#146;s financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenues or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources that is material to investors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Except for BSN Medical and AbilityOne (see Note 36 of Notes to the Accounts), no other related party has had material transactions or loans with Smith
	&amp; Nephew over the last three financial years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL
	REPORTING STANDARDS (&#147;IFRS&#148;)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Under European regulation, from 2005 Smith &amp;
	Nephew will be required to publish its financial statements under IFRS. The transition is being managed internally by a Project Committee reporting to a Steering Committee which is chaired by the Finance Director.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	40
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Project Committee has performed a full assessment of the extant standards and their impact on both the reported financial
	statements and underlying business processes, and continues to monitor the progress of standards yet to be finalised. Bi-annual reports have been made to the Audit Committee on the likely impact of these changes. Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s transition
	plan is in place and implementation has commenced, with changes to internal reporting systems, training and required amendments to financial processes underway. Management believes that the Group is on track to meet the convergence timetable and
	throughout 2004 intends to ensure appropriate communication of this internally and to investors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Based on those standards currently in issue and management&#146;s understanding of future developments, the major differences in accounting policies which are expected to impact Smith &amp; Nephew are for employee benefits (in particular
	pensions accounting and a requirement for the expensing of all share options granted) acquisition goodwill which will no longer be amortised but will be subject to annual testing for impairment and increased recognition of intangible assets arising
	on acquisition. In addition, management expects the recognition criteria for deferred tax will change, resulting in a net write back of provisions, principally related to goodwill set-off against reserves. Although the standards on Financial
	Instruments have necessitated a change to the process of Smith &amp; Nephew&#146;s hedging practice and enhancements to documentation, the overall hedging strategy remains essentially unchanged. Management intends to continue monitoring developments
	as the standards and recognised practices evolve.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	41
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	US GAAP
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Smith &amp; Nephew prepares its accounts in accordance with UK GAAP which differ in certain respects from US GAAP. Reconciliations of profit for the financial year and
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_21"></A>
	shareholders&#146; funds are set out in Note 40 of Notes to the Accounts.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	US GAAP profit for the financial year in 2003 is
	&pound;19.3m higher than UK GAAP mainly due to the non-amortisation of goodwill of &pound;18.5m, offset partly by higher amortisation of other intangible fixed assets of &pound;9.9m. Other principal adjustments to profit include: a charge of
	&pound;4.5m under SFAS 123 for stock based compensation (staff costs); a charge of &pound;8.5m for pensions reflecting amortisation of a larger deficit and the use of lower interest rates for discounting liabilities; and a credit of &pound;14.1m on
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_22"></A>
	the difference in deferred taxation accounting for intangibles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Shareholders&#146; funds in 2003 are
	&pound;69.1m higher than UK GAAP principally due to the non-amortisation of goodwill, &pound;49.1m; different recognition criteria for intangible assets and goodwill, &pound;54.8m; dividends on a declared rather than a proposed basis, &pound;28.9m;
	inclusion of a minimum pension liability, &pound;88.0m; and lower taxation provision due to these adjustments of &pound;35.6m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Prospects
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Smith &amp; Nephew have published expectations of future results on a UK GAAP
	basis in &#147;Outlook and Trend Information&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	New accounting standards in the US
	which may affect US GAAP results are detailed in Note 39 of the Notes to the Accounts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	42
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage48"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_23"></A>

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Ages of and Appointments held by Directors
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Dudley G. Eustace, Chairman, age 67, was appointed Deputy Chairman in 1999 and Chairman in January 2000. Chairman of the Nominations Committee. He is the
	non-executive Chairman of Sendo Holdings plc and a non-executive director of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines NV, Aegon NV, Hagenmeyer NV and Royal KPN NV. From March to August 2003 he was interim Chief Financial Officer of Royal Ahold N.V. and remained a
	member of the Corporate Executive Board until December 2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sir Christopher J.
	O&#146;Donnell, Chief Executive, age 57, joined the Group in 1988 as managing director of the Group&#146;s medical division and was appointed a director of Smith &amp; Nephew in 1992. He was appointed Chief Executive in 1997 and is a member of the
	Nominations Committee. He is a non-executive director of BOC Group Plc. Previously he held senior positions with UK and US companies in the medical engineering and devices industry.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Peter Hooley, Finance Director, age 57, joined the Group and was appointed Finance Director in 1991. He is a non-executive director of Cobham plc.
	Previously he held senior financial positions with Matthew Hall and BICC.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Dr. Pamela J.
	Kirby, age 50, appointed a director in March 2002 and is a member of the Remuneration Committee. She was formerly Chief Executive Officer of Quintiles Transnational Corporation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Warren D. Knowlton, age 57, appointed a director in November 2000. He is Chairman of the Audit Committee and a member of the Remuneration Committee.
	He is Group Chief Executive of Morgan Crucible Plc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Brian Larcombe, age 50, appointed a
	director in March 2002 and is a member of the Audit Committee. He is Chief Executive of 3i Group plc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Richard De Schutter, age 63, appointed a director in January 2001 and is a member of the Audit Committee and the Remuneration Committee. He is a non-executive Chairman of Incyte Corporation and a non-executive director of
	Varian Inc., MedPointe Pharmaceuticals, Metaphore Pharmaceuticals, and Navicure Inc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Dr.
	Rolf W. H. Stomberg, age 63, a director since 1998. He is senior independent director, Chairman of the Remuneration Committee and a member of the Audit Committee and Nominations Committee. He is Chairman of Management Consulting Group PLC and a
	non-executive director of Scania AB, Reed Elsevier plc, TPG Group Plc, Hoyer GmbH and Deutsche BP AG.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Other Directors
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Sir Timothy Lankester retired from the Board on 29 April 2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
