<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	On 23 June 2003 the 5&#189;%
	&pound;1.00 cumulative preference shares were cancelled and in consideration the preference shareholders were paid &pound;1.38 per share on 7 July 2003. The 5&#189;% cumulative preference shares were denominated in sterling, were non-voting and
	carried preferential rights to dividends and distribution on winding up.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	93
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage99"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	25
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Share Option Plans
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Smith &amp; Nephew Sharesave Plan (2002) (adopted by shareholders on 3 April 2002) is available to all employees in the UK employed by participating Group
	companies, subject to three months&#146; service. The scheme provides for employees to save up to &pound;250 per month and are given an option to acquire a set number of shares based on the committed amount to be saved. The option price is the
	higher of the nominal value and not less than 80% of the middle market quotation of the Ordinary Shares on the three dealing days preceding the date of invitation. The Smith &amp; Nephew International Sharesave Plan (2002) is offered to employees in
	Australia, Austria, Canada, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Hong Kong, Italy, South Korea, Mexico, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Arab Emirates. Employees in Belgium, Italy, the
	Netherlands and France are able to participate respectively in the Smith &amp; Nephew Belgian Sharesave Plan (2002), the Smith &amp; Nephew Italian Sharesave Plan (2002), the Smith &amp; Nephew Dutch Sharesave Plan (2002) and the Smith &amp; Nephew
	France Sharesave Plan (2002). Participants in Ireland are able to participate in the Smith &amp; Nephew Irish Employee Share Option Scheme. These plans operate on a substantially similar basis to the Smith &amp; Nephew Sharesave Plan (2002). Options
	are no longer issued under the Smith &amp; Nephew Employee Share Option Scheme (adopted by shareholders on 14 May 1981) and the Smith &amp; Nephew 1991 Overseas Employee Share Option Scheme (adopted by shareholders on 25 May 1990) but options remain
	to be exercised under these two schemes. Together all of the plans referred to above are termed the &#147;Employee Schemes&#148;.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Smith &amp; Nephew 1985 Share Option Scheme (adopted by shareholders on 9 May 1985), the Smith &amp; Nephew 1990 International Executive Share Option Scheme
	(adopted by shareholders on 15 May 1990), the Smith &amp; Nephew 2001 UK Approved Share Option Plan, the Smith &amp; Nephew 2001 UK Unapproved Share Option Plan and the Smith &amp; Nephew 2001 US Share Plan (adopted by shareholders on 4 April 2001),
	together termed the &#147;Executive Schemes&#148;, are operated at the discretion of the Board of Directors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Under the terms of the Executive Schemes, the Remuneration Committee, consisting of Non-Executive Directors, may select full-time employees of the Group for the
	grant of options to acquire Ordinary Shares in the Company. Options granted under the Smith &amp; Nephew 2001 US Share Plan (the &#147;US Plan&#148;) are to acquire ADSs. The option price will not be less than the market value of an Ordinary Share,
	or the nominal value if higher. The market value will be the quoted price on the business day preceding the date of grant or the quoted price on the date of grant. For Executive Schemes adopted in 2001, the market value will be the average quoted
	price of an Ordinary Share for the three business days preceding the date of grant or, for the US Plan, the average quoted price of an ADS for the three business days preceding the date of grant or the quoted price on the date of grant. With the
	exception of options granted under the 2001 US Plan, the exercise of options granted from 1997 are subject to achievement of a performance condition. Options granted under the 2001 US Plan are not subject to performance conditions but become
	exercisable as to 10% after one year, 30% after two years, 60% after three years and the remaining balance after four years. The 1990 International Executive Share Option Scheme and the 2001 UK Unapproved Share Option Plan are open to senior
	managers outside the UK and the 1990 International Executive Share Option Scheme and the US Plan are open to senior managers in the US, Canada, Mexico and Puerto Rico.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Under the Executive Schemes, the number of Ordinary Shares over which options may be granted is limited so that the number of shares
	issued or that may be issued under the Executive Schemes during the ten years preceding the date of grant shall not exceed 5% of the Ordinary Share capital at the date of grant. The total number of Ordinary Shares which may be issuable in any
	ten-year period under all employee share schemes operated by the Company may not exceed 10% of the Ordinary Share capital at the date of grant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Employees in the US are able to participate in the Employee Stock Purchase Plan, which gives them the opportunity to acquire shares, in the form of ADSs, at a
	discount of 15% (or more if the shares appreciate in value during the plan&#146;s quarterly purchase period) to the market price, through a regular savings plan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	94
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The weighted average fair values
	of options granted in 2003, 2002 and 2001 were calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model for traded options.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	95
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage101"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	25.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Share Option Plans &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The following assumptions were used in calculating the fair values of options granted for Employee Schemes: dividend yield of 1.1% (2002 &#151; 1.3%, 2001 &#151;
	1.1%), expected volatility of 23.3% (2002 &#151; 19.6%, 2001 &#151; 19.4%), risk free interest rate of 4.6% (2002 &#151; 4.5%, 2001 &#151; 5.0%) and expected life of 3.6 years (2002 &#151; 3.6 years, 2001 &#151; 5.0 years).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The following assumptions were used in calculating the fair values of options granted
	for Executive Schemes: dividend yield of 1.1% (2002 &#151; 1.3%, 2001 &#151; 1.1%), expected volatility of 22.0% (2002 &#151; 19.6%, 2001 &#151; 19.4%), risk free interest rate of 4.6% (2002 &#151; 5.2%, 2001 &#151; 4.9%) and expected life of 5.6
	years (2002 &#151; 5.6 years, 2001 &#151; 10.0 years).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Because options
	vest over several years and there are restrictions as to exercise and additional options grants are expected, the effects of these hypothetical calculations are not likely to be representative of similar future calculations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Summarised information about options outstanding under the share option schemes at 31
	December 2003 is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	As the employee schemes are UK
	Inland Revenue approved Save As You Earn schemes or similar schemes, the Company is exempt from accounting for the difference between the share option price and the market value at the grant date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Until 31 December 2002 the Company used a qualifying employee share ownership trust
	(&#147;QUEST&#148;) to acquire Smith &amp; Nephew plc Ordinary Shares for the transfer to employees exercising options under the Smith &amp; Nephew Employee Share Option Scheme. The QUEST was not used in 2003 and the Company does not intend to use
	it in the future. The trustee of the QUEST was Smith &amp; Nephew Employees Trustees Limited, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company. During 2002, the QUEST subscribed for 950,317 shares at a cost of &pound;2.3m and transferred a total of 950,317
	shares to employees on the exercise of options for consideration of &pound;1.4m. All employees of UK Group subsidiary companies, including Executive Directors of the Company, were potential beneficiaries under the QUEST.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	96
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Net exchange gains of
	&pound;45.7m (2002 &#151; gains of &pound;68.2m) arising on foreign currency net borrowings are included within the &pound;3.8m (2002 &#151; &pound;9.1m) translational differences on foreign currency net investments. The cumulative amount of
	goodwill charged to reserves is &pound;275.8m (2002 &#151; &pound;292.3m) against which &pound;116.0m of merger relief has been offset. The decrease is due to goodwill written back on the disposal of AbilityOne of &pound;8.2m and exchange movements
	of &pound;8.3m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

</TD>

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	97

<A NAME="eolPage103"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	26.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Reserves &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In accordance with the exemption permitted by Section 230(3) of the Companies Act 1985, the Parent Company has not presented its own profit and loss account. The
	attributable loss for the year dealt with in the accounts of the Parent Company is &pound;21.1m (2002 &#151; profit of &pound;3.8m).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The profit and loss account in 2001 and 2002 in the Group and Parent Company have been restated for the adoption of UITF 38 (Note 27).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	On 23 June 2003, following the cancellation of the 5&#189;% &pound;1.00 cumulative
	preference shares (Note 24), a capital redemption reserve of &pound;0.3m was established in the Parent Company. This reserve was extinguished during 2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	There is no significant effect
	on the Group and Parent profit and loss accounts on adoption of UITF 38 so no restatements have been made.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	29.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Currency Translation
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The exchange rates used for the translation of currencies into pounds sterling that have the most significant impact on the Group results were:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

	&pound;7.2m of deferred consideration, net of amortisation, relating to the Collagenase acquisition in 2000 has been written back to goodwill as it is no longer payable (Note 13).

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Acquisitions in 2002
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	On 28 March 2002, the
	Group acquired ORATEC Interventions, Inc., (&#147;ORATEC&#148;), at a net cost of &pound;191.2m in cash. Further fair value adjustments have been made in the first full financial period after acquisition.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Total cost of acquisition
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	69.3
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	There was no material difference
	between the fair value and book value of net assets acquired.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Group capital expenditure contracted but not provided for amounted to &pound;2.6m (2002 &#151; &pound;4.3m).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Under the Group&#146;s acquisition and joint development agreements with NUCRYST
	Pharmaceuticals Corp., amounts of up to &pound;4.2m (2002 &#151; &pound;4.7m) could become payable on achievement of certain milestones related to regulatory and reimbursement approvals with a further &pound;25.1m (2002 &#151; &pound;28.0m)
	contingent on achievement of sales milestones.
</FONT>
</P>

</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The parent has given guarantees
	to banks to support liabilities under foreign exchange contracts and cross guarantees to support overdrafts. Such guarantees are not considered to be liabilities as all subsidiary undertakings are trading as going concerns.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group is party to legal proceedings, in the normal course of business, which it is
	considered will not result in any material adverse effect on the Group&#146;s results of operations or financial position.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	33.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Post-Retirement Benefits
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group sponsors pension plans for its employees in most of the countries in which it has major operating companies. Pension plans are established under the laws
	of the relevant country, funded by the payment of contributions to, and the assets held by, separate trust funds or insurance companies. In those countries where there is no company-sponsored pension plan, state benefits are considered adequate.
	Employees&#146; retirement benefits are the subject of regular management review.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	For many years, the Group&#146;s major pension plans in the United Kingdom (&#147;UK Plan&#148;) and the United States (&#147;US Plan&#148;) were of the defined benefit type. However, from 2003 all new employees were provided
	with a defined contribution pension plan. Existing employees were given the opportunity to choose whether to remain in their existing plan or change to the new arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The pension cost for the UK Plan and the US Plan has been determined by independent qualified actuaries, using the projected unit
	method. Under the projected unit method, the current service cost will increase as the members of the defined benefit plans approach retirement. The market related actuarial assumptions at the valuation dates and a breakdown of the pension costs are
	as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Actuarial assumptions:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<HR WIDTH="0" SIZE="3" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" COLOR="#FFFFFF">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TABLE WIDTH="14%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%">
<HR SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" ALIGN="LEFT">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	(i)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Variations from regular costs arise from the surplus/deficit in the two principal plans and are amortised using the percentage of payroll method over the weighted average of expected
	pensionable payroll and remaining service lives of current employees in the plans.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	At the dates of the most recent actuarial valuations for the purposes of SSAP 24 in September and December 2002, the aggregate market value of the assets of the UK
	Plan and the US Plan was &pound;230m (2002 &#151; &pound;268m: valuations in September and December 2001) representing 78% of plan liabilities for accrued benefits, including allowance for projected future increases in salaries, resulting in a net
	deficit of &pound;64.5m (2002 &#151; 93% and a net deficit of &pound;19.8m). The estimated deficit of these plans at 31 December 2003 was &pound;55m (2002 &#151; &pound;80m).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The unamortised balance of the UK Plan and US Plan deficits was &pound;70.1m (2002 &#151; deficit &pound;20.8m).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The contributions made to the UK Plan and the US Plan in the accounting period were
	&pound;8.5m (2002 &#151;&pound;2.6m) and &pound;10.4m (2002&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;&pound;5.2m), respectively. The agreed contribution rates for 2004 and 2005 are 11% of pensionable earnings plus a supplementary payment of &pound;4.3m in each year to the
	UK Plan and 7% of pensionable earnings plus a supplementary payment of &pound;10m in 2004 to the US Plan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	103
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage109"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	33.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Post-Retirement Benefits &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Included in debtors due after more than one year are prepayments of &pound;7.1m (2002 &#151; &pound;5.3m) and included in creditors are accruals due within one year
	of &pound;4.0m (2002&#151;&pound;6.4m) relating to the funding of certain Group pension plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group recharges the UK pension plan with the costs of administration and independent advisers. The amount recharged in the year was &pound;0.6m (2002 &#151; &pound;0.4m, 2001 &#151; &pound;0.7m). The amount receivable at
	31&nbsp;December 2003 was &pound;0.1m (2002 &#151; &pound;0.1m).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The
	cost of providing healthcare benefits after retirement of &pound;1.1m (2002 &#151; &pound;0.8m, 2001 &#151; &pound;0.1m) are determined by independent qualified actuaries. The unfunded liability of &pound;8.8m (2002 &#151; &pound;9.4m) in respect of
	the accrued healthcare benefits is included in provisions. The principal actuarial assumptions in determining the cost of providing healthcare benefits are those in the UK and the US:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

	&nbsp;

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The combined operating and
	finance costs that would have been charged in 2003 under FRS 17 of &pound;14.9m compares with the cost under SSAP 24 of &pound;14.2m (2002 &#151; FRS 17 amount of &pound;8.2m compares with the cost under SSAP 24 of &pound;7.8m).
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">

<A NAME="eolPage112"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	34.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Post-Retirement Benefits (FRS 17) &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The cost of providing healthcare benefits after retirement under FRS 17 of &pound;0.8m (&pound;1.1m charge under SSAP 24) is determined by independent actuaries and
	would be charged to operating profit in 2003 (2002 &#151; &pound;0.8m charged in 2002 compared with a &pound;0.8m charge under SSAP 24). The principal actuarial assumptions in determining the cost of providing healthcare benefits are those in the UK
	and the US and would be as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR WIDTH="0" SIZE="3" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" COLOR="#FFFFFF">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Smith &amp; Nephew
	Employees&#146; Share Trust (the &#147;Trust&#148;) was established to hold shares relating to the long-term incentive plan referred to in the &#147;Remuneration Report&#148;. Holdings of the Parent Company&#146;s Own Shares in respect of the Trust
	are disclosed in Note 27. The Trust is administered by an independent professional trust company resident in Jersey and is funded by a loan from the Parent Company. The costs of the Trust are charged to the profit and loss account as they accrue. A
	dividend waiver is in place in respect of those shares held under the long-term incentive plan that are yet to vest. The waiver represents less than 1% of the total dividends paid.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	At 31 December 2003, the Trust held 1.6m (2002 &#151; 1.5m) Ordinary Shares at an aggregate cost of &pound;5.6m (2002 &#151;
	&pound;5.2m). 1.1m (2002 &#151; 0.6m) shares, with an original cost of &pound;3.5m (2002 &#151; &pound;2.0m), have vested and are held under option for the benefit of directors and employees. 0.5m shares, at an aggregate cost of &pound;2.1m, are
	included within shareholders&#146; funds on the Group and Parent balance sheets. The market value of these shares at 31 December 2003 was &pound;2.3m (2002 &#151; &pound;3.4m).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	36.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Related Party Transactions with Joint Venture and Associated Undertaking
</B>
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In the course of normal operations, the Group traded on an arm&#146;s-length basis with its joint venture BSN Medical from 1 April 2001 and associated undertaking
	AbilityOne from 27 March 2002 until 12 September 2003. The aggregated transactions, which have not been disclosed elsewhere in the financial statements, are summarised below:
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	4.0
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	3.3
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Relating to capital transactions (included above)
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">

	&#150;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	1.6
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	1.3
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TD>

</TD>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">

	Audit fees incurred by Group pension schemes (not included above)
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">

</FONT>

	0.1
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<HR SIZE="3" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Of the total auditors&#146;
	remuneration &pound;2.3m (2002&#151;&pound;1.3m, 2001&#151;&pound;0.8m) relates to statutory and other certifications and services. Also, of the total auditors&#146; remuneration in 2003 &pound;3.7m relates to the unsuccessful public offers to
	purchase Centerpulse AG and InCentive Capital AG.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	38.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Post Balance Sheet Events
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	On 16 March 2004, Smith &amp; Nephew completed the acquisition of Midland Medical Technologies (&#147;MMT&#148;), the global market leader in metal-on-metal hip
	resurfacing for &pound;67m in cash and notes. Additional payments of &pound;33m in cash and notes are contingent upon certain regulatory and development milestones being met. MMT achieved sales in the 2003 calendar year of &pound;20m.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	39.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	New Accounting Standards
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	New Accounting Standards in the UK &#151; FRS 17
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	FRS 17 &#151; Retirement Benefits was issued in November 2000. Full implementation has been deferred until 1&nbsp;January 2005. Some disclosure requirements are effective for periods prior to this date. The standard requires that financial
	statements reflect at fair value the assets and liabilities arising from an employer&#146;s retirement benefit obligations and related funding. Current and past service costs are charged to operating expense in the period in which they are earned,
	the interest cost on accrued liabilities less expected return on assets is charged as net finance costs and changes in the value of the related assets and liabilities are taken to reserves in the period. Had FRS 17 been implemented at 31 December
	2003, the Group would have reported a retirement liability, net of related deferred tax, of &pound;86.5m (2002 &#151; &pound;80.2m), which compares with &pound;1.7m (2002 &#151; &pound;4.8m) recorded in the balance sheet under the existing rules.
	The impact of FRS 17 on retained earnings for 2003 would have been to reduce retained earnings by &pound;84.8m (2002 &#151; &pound;75.4m) (Note 34).
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	New Accounting Standards in the US &#151; FIN 46
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	FIN 46 &#151; Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities was issued in January 2003 and subsequently revised in December 2003. It requires additional disclosures to be made in financial statements issued after January 2003 and becomes
	fully effective for accounting periods ending after 15 March 2004. FIN 46 requires entities to be consolidated if their financial affairs are being supported by a third party even if that third party is not an equity holder. Management does not
	believe that this standard will result in any additional entities being consolidated into the Group.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	108
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage114"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	40.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Differences Between Accounting Principles Generally Accepted in the UK and US
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Group accounts are prepared in accordance with UK GAAP which differ in certain respects from US&nbsp;GAAP. Those differences which have a significant effect on
	the Group&#146;s profit for the financial year and shareholders&#146; funds are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Prior to 1998, goodwill arising on acquisitions was set off against reserves. On
	disposal of such businesses, goodwill previously set off against reserves is charged to profit or loss on disposal. Since 1998, goodwill and other intangible fixed assets purchased by way of acquisition have been capitalised and written off over a
	period not exceeding 20 years. Under US GAAP, goodwill and other intangible fixed assets purchased prior to 2002 would have been capitalised and amortised over their expected useful lives. Commencing 2002, goodwill would not be amortised and would
	be subject to an annual impairment review, whereas other intangible assets would continue to be capitalised and amortised over their useful lives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Fair value adjustments to goodwill may be made in the first full financial period after acquisition. Under US GAAP, these may only be made within one year of
	acquisition. Thus, any adjustments post this period would be taken to the profit and loss account for the year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Goodwill arising on the formation of the joint venture is not amortised but is subject to annual impairment review. Under US GAAP, prior to 2002 this goodwill would
	be amortised. Commencing 2002, this goodwill would not be amortised.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Joint Venture and Associated Undertaking
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	One of the components of the goodwill in the joint venture is the difference between the
	fair value of consideration given and the book value of net assets acquired in the joint venture by the Group. Under US&nbsp;GAAP, this gain would be unrealised and would not be recognised.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The results of the joint venture are included within turnover, operating profit,
	interest and taxation. The results of the associated undertaking are included within operating profit, interest and taxation. Under US&nbsp;GAAP, the Group&#146;s share of the after tax profits of the joint venture and associated undertaking would
	be reflected in the income statement as a single line item and its net investment in the joint venture would be included as a single line item in the balance sheet with the investment in the Group&#146;s associated undertaking.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Post-Retirement Benefits
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Projected benefit liabilities are discounted using long-term investment returns and surpluses and deficits are amortised over the employees&#146; service lives.
	Under US GAAP, pension liabilities would be discounted using corporate bond rates and surpluses and deficits within 10% limits would not be amortised and would thus have no immediate impact on pension costs. In addition, under US GAAP where the
	value of plan assets is below the value of the liabilities valued on an accumulated benefit obligation basis, the deficit would be recognised immediately through other comprehensive income.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Trade Investments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Trade investments are stated in the balance sheet at cost less provision for any permanent diminution in value and any movements in provisions are taken to the
	profit and loss account for the year. Under US&nbsp;GAAP, trade investments would be stated at market value and movements in market value would be taken to shareholders&#146; equity via comprehensive income for the year.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Factoring of Debts
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Trade debtors are stated in the balance sheet net of non-returnable proceeds received. Under US GAAP, trade debtors would be stated gross and proceeds received
	would be included in borrowings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Derivative Instruments and Hedging
	Activities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Derivative instruments in respect of anticipated future transactions, interest rate risks and intragroup equity investments are
	accounted for as hedges. Under US GAAP, all derivative instruments (including
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	109
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage115"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	40.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Differences Between Accounting Principles Generally Accepted in the UK and US &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	those embedded in other contracts) are recognised as either assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet at their fair
	values. US GAAP prescribes requirements for designation and documentation of hedging relationships and ongoing assessments of effectiveness in order to qualify for hedge accounting. Changes in the fair value of derivatives that are designated and
	qualify as part of a hedge transaction would be recorded each period in current earnings or other comprehensive income, depending on the type of hedge transaction. Changes in the fair value of derivatives that do not qualify for hedge accounting
	would be recognised each period in profit for the financial year.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Forward Foreign Exchange Contracts
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Forward foreign exchange contracts
	in respect of anticipated future transactions are treated as hedges and not marked to market. Gains and losses thereon are recognised only when the exposure that is being hedged is itself recognised. Under US GAAP, such contracts would be valued at
	the forward rates at the balance sheet date with the gains and losses included in profit for the financial year. On maturity of the contract the gain/loss not recognised to date would be recognised in profit for the financial year.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Rate Swaps
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Interest rate swaps used to fix interest rates on the Group&#146;s major exposures are treated as hedges and not marked to market. Gains and
	losses thereon are recognised only when the exposure that is being hedged is itself recognised. Under US GAAP, these swaps would not be treated as hedges, due to the additional documentation requirement, and gains and losses on valuing such
	contracts at the balance sheet date would be included in profit for the financial year.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency Rate Swaps
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Currency swaps are used to hedge intra Group equity
	investments. Realised and unrealised gains/losses are not recognised in profit for the year but are recorded as movements in reserves. Receivables and payables on currency swaps are included within debtors and creditors respectively. Under US GAAP,
	these swaps would be separately classified into current asset derivatives, current liabilities derivatives and non-current liabilities derivatives.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Dividends
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Dividends are provided in the period to which
	they relate and, in the case of proposed final dividends, on the basis of proposals by the Directors. Under US GAAP, dividends would be provided for in the accounts for the period in which they are declared.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Taxation
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Deferred taxation is recognised on most timing differences. This is generally consistent with US GAAP, except that deferred taxation is provided on goodwill
	acquired prior to 1998, which has been set off against reserves and on which taxation benefits have been received. Under US GAAP, as goodwill acquired prior to 1998 would not have been set off against reserves, the deferred taxation provided under
	UK GAAP would not be required. Furthermore, under US GAAP, a deferred tax liability would be provided on intangible assets acquired subject to book amortisation where no tax relief is available.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Acquired in-Process Research and Development
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Acquired in-process research and development is not separately identified and therefore forms part of the goodwill arising on acquisition. Under US GAAP, acquired
	in-process research and development would be identified separately from goodwill and charged to the profit and loss account on the date of acquisition.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Leases
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The criteria for capitalising leases under UK
	GAAP differ from those under US GAAP. As a result, certain leases which are classified as operating leases under UK GAAP would have been capitalised under US&nbsp;GAAP.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	110
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage116"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	40.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Differences Between Accounting Principles Generally Accepted in the UK and US &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Discontinued Activities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Under UK GAAP, the results of operations arising from discontinued operations are presented in the profit and loss account under the relevant captions and the profit/(loss) on their disposal is reported as a separate line item after
	operating income and before interest. Under US GAAP, the results of operations from discontinued operations and the profit/(loss) on their disposal are reported as separate line items immediately before net income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Exceptional Items
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Items classified as exceptional under UK GAAP do not meet the definition of extraordinary under US&nbsp;GAAP and therefore under US GAAP these would be classified
	as operating expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Staff Costs
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Under UK GAAP, the Group does not account for stock based compensation. Under US GAAP, stock based compensation would be recognised under the fair value recognition
	provisions of FAS 123 &#151; Accounting for Stock Based Compensation and charged to the profit and loss account for the year.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	111
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage117"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>

</B>
</FONT>
</TD>

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Differences Between Accounting Principles Generally Accepted in the UK and US &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Effect of Differences
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The
	effect of the adjustments to attributable profit for the year and to shareholders&#146; funds that would be required if US GAAP were to be applied instead of UK GAAP is summarised as follows. The condensed consolidated income presented below
	reflects the adjustments to attributable profit for the year.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	)

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	(1.6

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Consolidated
	Statement of Cash Flows
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The US GAAP cash flow statement reports
	changes in cash and cash equivalents, which includes short-term highly liquid investments. Under UK GAAP, cash flows are presented separately for operating activities, dividends from joint ventures, returns on investments and servicing of finance,
	taxation, investing activities and financing activities. US GAAP requires only three categories of cash flow activity to be reported: operating, investing and financing. Cash flows from taxation and returns on investments and servicing of finance
	shown under UK GAAP would be included as operating activities under US GAAP. The payment of dividends would be included as a financing activity under US GAAP.
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The categories of cash flow activity under US GAAP are summarised as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_119"></A>

</TD>

	4.13p

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Additional Information
	Required by US GAAP in Respect of Deferred Taxation
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">

	follows:
</FONT>

	The losses carried forward have
	expiration dates that range from 2008 to 2020.
</FONT>

</FONT>

<A NAME="eolPage122"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	40.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Differences Between Accounting Principles Generally Accepted in the UK and US &#151; (continued)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_122"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Additional Information Required by US GAAP in Respect of the Group&#146;s Two Principal Pension Plans
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The two principal pension plans are those in the UK and the US. The pension cost for these plans computed in accordance with the requirements of US GAAP
	comprises:
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="90%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="75%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="5%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The assumption for the expected
	long-term rate of return on assets is based on separate long-term assumptions for each of the major assets classes weighted by the asset allocation. The long-term assumptions for bonds are based on long-term market yields at the accounting date. The
	long-term rate of return on equities is the Group&#146;s best estimate of future returns with consideration having been given to long-term historic real returns achieved on equities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	117
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage123"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The measurement date for the UK
	Plan and the US Plan is 31 December.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In the UK Plan, the assets
	principally comprise UK and other listed equities, bank deposits and UK Government index-linked stocks. In the US Plan, the assets principally comprise US equities, other listed equities and fixed income securities.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The long-term investment
	strategy for the Smith &amp; Nephew UK Pension Fund (&#147;the UK Plan&#148;) is for significant index linked and fixed interest investments to be held so that in the short to medium term the income from them exceeds the excess of benefits over
	contributions. The balance of the UK Plan&#146;s investments will be invested in equities and property.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	118
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The long-term investment
	strategy for the Smith &amp; Nephew US Pension Plan (&#147;the US Plan&#148;) is a long-term rate of return on assets that is at least 5% to 6% greater than the rate of inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index. This target rate of return
	for the Plan is based upon the assumption that future real rates of return will be close to the historical long run rates of return experienced for each asset class. Market performance varies and a real rate of return of between 5% and 6% may not be
	achievable during some periods.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The US Plan is not allowed to have a
	direct shareholding in Smith &amp; Nephew plc or associated companies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	A
	reconciliation of the projected benefit obligation and the fair value of plan assets is shown in the following tables:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

	point change in the rate of medical cost inflation would increase/(decrease) the accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation as follows:

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	(i)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Represents the excess of amounts written off over recoveries.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	122
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage128"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">
	SHAREHOLDER RETURN
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Dividend History
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Following the capital restructuring and dividend reduction in 2000 the
	Group adopted a policy of increasing its dividend cover. This was intended to increase the financing capability of the Group for acquisitions and other investments. Over the last three years the dividend has been increased in line with inflation.
	Dividend cover (the ratio of attributable earnings before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items, as set out in the &#147;Five Year Record&#148;, to ordinary dividends) has increased from 3.0 times in 2001 to 3.7 times in 2003.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Smith &amp; Nephew has paid dividends on its Ordinary Shares in each year since 1937. An interim
	dividend in respect of each fiscal year is normally declared in August and from 2002 onwards paid in November, and the final dividend for each year is normally recommended by the Board of Directors in the following February and paid in May after
	approval by shareholders at the Company&#146;s Annual General Meeting.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Future dividends
	of Smith &amp; Nephew will be dependent upon future earnings, the future financial condition of the Group, the Board&#146;s dividend policy and the additional factors that might affect the business of the Group set out in &#147;Special Note
	Regarding Forward-Looking Statements&#148; (page 3) and &#147;Risk Factors&#148; (page 20).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The following table shows the dividends on each Ordinary Share (as increased by the associated UK tax credit, but before deduction of withholding taxes) for the fiscal years 1999 through 2003. The associated UK tax credit was reduced from
	20% to 10% for dividends paid on or after 6 April 1999. If approved by shareholders, 2003&#146;s final dividend will be payable on 14 May 2004. The dividends, which are declared in pence per share in respect of each fiscal year, have been translated
	into US cents per share at the Noon Buying Rate at each respective payment date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

	tax credit, equivalent to US$3.105 per ADS) was paid.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Final Dividend
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Ordinary Shares will trade ex-dividend on both the London and New York Stock Exchanges from 21 April 2004 and the record date will be 23 April 2004 in respect of this
	year&#146;s proposed final dividend to be paid on 14 May 2004.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Information for
	Holders of Ordinary Shares
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Payment of cash dividends
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	Shareholders who
	wish their dividends to be paid directly to a bank or building society and who have not already completed an electronic bank transfer mandate should contact the Company&#146;s registrars.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Dividend re-investment plan
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Company has a dividend
	re-investment plan that offers shareholders, except those in North America, the opportunity to invest their cash dividends in Smith &amp; Nephew Ordinary shares, which are purchased in the market at competitive dealing costs. Application forms for
	re-investing the 2003 final dividend are available from Lloyds TSB Registrars who administer the plan on behalf of the Company. Applications for re-investment should be returned to the Company&#146;s registrars by 27 April 2004.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	UK capital gains tax
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	For the purposes of UK capital gains tax the price of Ordinary Shares on 31 March 1982 was 35.04p.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Smith &amp; Nephew share price
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s share price is quoted daily in UK national newspapers, as well as on Ceefax and
	Teletext and at www.londonstockexchange.com where it is updated at intervals throughout the day. The Financial Times Cityline Service, telephone +44 (0)906 0034043, provides an up to the minute share price. A fee is charged for this service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Low-cost dealing service
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	A postal and telephone facility that provides a simple low-cost method of buying and selling Smith &amp; Nephew shares is available through Hoare Govett Limited. For information
	contact Hoare Govett Ltd., 250 Bishopsgate, London EC2M 4AA, UK. Telephone +44 (0)20 7678 8300.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Smith &amp; Nephew corporate ISA
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Company has a corporate Individual Savings Account (ISA), for UK shareholders, administered by Lloyds TSB
	Registrars. For information about this service please contact their helpline on telephone +44 (0)870 2424 244.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Shareview
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	To view information about Smith &amp; Nephew shareholdings on the internet, register at www.shareview.com, the Lloyds TSB
	enquiry and portfolio management service for shareholders. When you have registered for shareview you will also be able to register your proxy instructions online and elect to receive future shareholder communications via the Company&#146;s website
	at www.smith-nephew.com.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	125
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage131"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Shareholder enquiries
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	For information
	about the AGM, shareholdings, dividends and changes to personal details all shareholders should contact: Lloyds TSB Registrars, The Causeway, Worthing, West Sussex BN99 6DS, UK. Telephone +44&nbsp;(0)870 600 3996.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Information for Holders of American Depositary Receipts (&#147;ADRs&#148;)
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	In the US, the Company&#146;s Ordinary Shares are traded in the form of ADSs, evidenced by ADRs, and trade on the NYSE under the symbol SNN. Each American Depositary Share
	represents five Ordinary Shares. Bank of New York is the authorised depositary bank for the company&#146;s ADR programme. A Global BuyDIRECT plan is available for US residents, enabling investment directly in ADSs with reduced brokerage commissions
	and service costs. For further information on Global BuyDIRECT contact: Bank of New York on +1-888-BNY-ADRS (toll-free) or visit www.adrbny.com.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Company furnishes the Bank of New York, as depositary, with this annual report containing Consolidated Financial Statements and an opinion thereon by its independent auditors.
	Such financial statements are prepared under UK GAAP. The annual report contains reconciliations of net income, cash flow and shareholders&#146; funds prepared under UK GAAP to those prepared under US GAAP. The Company also furnishes the Bank of New
	York with semi-annual reports prepared in conformity with UK GAAP, which contain unaudited interim consolidated financial information. Upon receipt thereof, the Bank of New York mails all such reports to recorded holders. The Company also furnishes
	to the Bank of New York all notices of shareholders&#146; meetings and other reports and communications that are made generally available to shareholders of the Company. The Bank of New York makes such notices, reports and communications available
	for inspection by recorded holders of ADSs and mails to all recorded holders of ADSs notices of shareholders&#146; meetings received by the Bank of New York.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Smith &amp; Nephew ADS price
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s ADS price is quoted daily in the Wall
	Street Journal and can be obtained from the official New York Stock Exchange website at www.nyse.com.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<I>
	ADR Enquiries
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	All enquiries regarding ADR holder accounts and payment of dividends should be addressed to Bank of New York, PO Box
	11258, Church Street Station, New York, NY 10286-1258, USA.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Annual General Meeting
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">
	The company&#146;s 67th Annual General Meeting is to be held on 6 May 2004 at 1.00 pm at the Lincoln Centre, 18&nbsp;Lincoln&#146;s Inn Fields, London WC2A 3ED,
	UK. Notice of the meeting is enclosed with an accompanying letter from the Chairman.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
